ChatGPT said:

To make the search bar functional, you need to:

✅ 1. Ensure Your views.py Supports Search

Update the view handling your product list to filter products based on the search query (q).

python
# views.py

from django.shortcuts import render
from .models import Product
from django.db.models import Q

def product_list(request):
    query = request.GET.get('q')
    products = Product.objects.all()

    if query:
        products = products.filter(
            Q(name__icontains=query) |
            Q(description__icontains=query)
        )

    context = {
        'products': products,
        'cart_count': get_cart_count(request),  # if using a cart system
    }
    return render(request, 'products.html', context)

✅ 2. Confirm Your urls.py Has the Right Route

Make sure your URL for the product list is correctly mapped and named products:

python
# urls.py

from django.urls import path
from . import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('products/', views.product_list, name='products'),
]

✅ 3. Your Search Form Is Already Correct

This part in your HTML is perfect:

html
<form method="GET" action="" class="...">
  ...
  <input type="text" name="q" ... value="{{ request.GET.q }}" />
  ...
</form>

It submits the query as ?q=your+search+term via GET to the current page, which is exactly what your Django view expects.

✅ 4. Optional: Improve Search Results Feedback

If no products match the query, this already handles it:

html
{% empty %}
<p class="col-span-full text-center text-gray-600 text-lg">No products available at the moment.</p>
{% endfor %}

You can change it to show a specific message if a query was submitted:

django
{% if request.GET.q %}
  <p class="col-span-full text-center text-gray-600 text-lg">
    No results found for "{{ request.GET.q }}"
  </p>
{% else %}
  <p class="col-span-full text-center text-gray-600 text-lg">
    No products available at the moment.
  </p>
{% endif %}

🔁 Summary

With these updates:

  • Your search input will filter by product name or description.

  • Search results will appear instantly on the same page (products.html).

  • Users will see feedback if no match is found.

Let me know if you want to expand the search to include categories or tags!

from django.shortcuts import render, redirect, get_object_or_404 from django.views.decorators.http import require_POST from django.views.decorators.csrf import csrf_exempt from django.contrib.auth.decorators import login_required from django.contrib import messages from django.http import JsonResponse, HttpResponse from django.db.models import Sum from django.utils.crypto import get_random_string from datetime import datetime, timedelta from decimal import Decimal from products.models import Product from .models import Cart as CartModel, CartItem, SavedItem from checkout.models import Order, OrderItem # -------------------------- # Utility: Get Cart (Session or User) # -------------------------- def get_cart_for_user(request): if request.user.is_authenticated: cart, _ = CartModel.objects.get_or_create(user=request.user, is_active=True) else: session_key = request.session.get("cart_session_key") if not session_key: session_key = get_random_string(32) request.session["cart_session_key"] = session_key cart, _ = CartModel.objects.get_or_create(session_key=session_key, is_active=True) return cart # -------------------------- # View: Add to Cart # -------------------------- @require_POST def add_to_cart(request): product_id = request.POST.get('product_id') quantity = int(request.POST.get('quantity', 1)) selected_image_url = request.POST.get('selected_image_url') product = get_object_or_404(Product, id=product_id) # Check stock if product.quantity < quantity: return JsonResponse({ 'status': 'error', 'message': f'Only {product.quantity} left in stock.' }, status=400) cart = get_cart_for_user(request) # Check if product already exists in cart if CartItem.objects.filter(cart=cart, product=product).exists(): return JsonResponse({ 'status': 'exists', 'message': 'Product already in cart.' }) # Add new item CartItem.objects.create( cart=cart, product=product, quantity=quantity, selected_image_url=selected_image_url ) # Reduce stock product.quantity -= quantity product.save() # Recalculate cart count cart_count = CartItem.objects.filter(cart=cart).aggregate(total=Sum('quantity'))['total'] or 0 return JsonResponse({ 'status': 'success', 'message': f'{product.name} added to cart.', 'cart_count': cart_count, 'available_quantity': product.quantity }) # -------------------------- # View: Cart Detail Page # -------------------------- def cart_detail(request): cart = get_cart_for_user(request) items = CartItem.objects.filter(cart=cart) coupon_code = request.session.get('coupon_code', '') subtotal = 0 cart_count = 0 today = datetime.today() delivery_range = f"{(today + timedelta(days=2)).strftime('%b %d')} – {(today + timedelta(days=5)).strftime('%b %d')}" # If the cart is now empty, clear the coupon if not items and 'coupon_code' in request.session: del request.session['coupon_code'] request.session.modified = True discounted_items = [] for item in items: product = item.product quantity = item.quantity original_price = float(product.price) price = float(product.get_discounted_price(coupon_code)) total = price * quantity subtotal += total cart_count += quantity discounted_items.append({ 'product': product, 'quantity': quantity, 'original_price': original_price, 'final_price': price, 'total': total, 'coupon_applied': coupon_code == product.coupon_code, 'estimated_delivery': delivery_range, 'selected_image_url': item.selected_image_url, }) delivery_fee = 300 if request.session.get('delivery_method', 'standard') == 'standard' else 600 discount = request.session.get('coupon_discount', 0) total_price = subtotal saved_items = [] if request.user.is_authenticated: saved_items = SavedItem.objects.filter(user=request.user) return render(request, 'cart/cart.html', { 'cart': cart, 'items': discounted_items, 'cart_count': cart_count, 'subtotal': subtotal, 'delivery_fee': delivery_fee, 'total_price': total_price, 'coupon_code': coupon_code, 'saved_items': saved_items, }) # -------------------------- # View: Apply Coupon # -------------------------- @csrf_exempt @require_POST def apply_coupon(request): coupon_code = request.POST.get('coupon_code') cart = get_cart_for_user(request) items = CartItem.objects.filter(cart=cart) total_discount = 0 for item in items: product = item.product if product.coupon_code == coupon_code: discount_percent = product.discount_percentage or 0 total_discount += (Decimal(str(product.price)) * item.quantity) * (discount_percent / Decimal('100')) request.session['coupon_code'] = coupon_code request.session['coupon_discount'] = round(float(total_discount), 2) request.session.modified = True messages.success(request, f"Coupon '{coupon_code}' applied successfully.") return redirect('cart:cart_detail') # -------------------------- # View: Remove from Cart # -------------------------- @require_POST def remove_from_cart(request, product_id): cart = get_cart_for_user(request) product = get_object_or_404(Product, id=product_id) try: cart_item = CartItem.objects.get(cart=cart, product=product) quantity = cart_item.quantity cart_item.delete() product.quantity += quantity product.save() messages.success(request, f"{product.name} removed from cart.") except CartItem.DoesNotExist: messages.error(request, f"{product.name} not found in cart.") return redirect('cart:cart_detail') # -------------------------- # View: Update Quantity # -------------------------- @require_POST def update_cart_quantity(request, product_id, action): cart = get_cart_for_user(request) product = get_object_or_404(Product, id=product_id) try: item = CartItem.objects.get(cart=cart, product=product) if action == 'increase': if product.quantity < 1: messages.error(request, f"No more {product.name} in stock.") else: item.quantity += 1 product.quantity -= 1 item.save() product.save() elif action == 'decrease': if item.quantity > 1: item.quantity -= 1 product.quantity += 1 item.save() product.save() else: item.delete() product.quantity += 1 product.save() except CartItem.DoesNotExist: messages.error(request, f"{product.name} not found in cart.") return redirect('cart:cart_detail') # -------------------------- # View: Save for Later # -------------------------- @login_required def save_for_later(request, product_id): if request.method == "POST": cart = CartModel.objects.filter(user=request.user, is_active=True).first() if not cart: return redirect('cart:cart_detail') item = get_object_or_404(CartItem, cart=cart, product_id=product_id) SavedItem.objects.get_or_create( user=request.user, product=item.product, variety=None ) item.delete() return redirect('cart:cart_detail') # -------------------------- # View: Move to Cart # -------------------------- @login_required def move_to_cart(request, item_id): if request.method == "POST": saved_item = get_object_or_404(SavedItem, id=item_id, user=request.user) cart, _ = CartModel.objects.get_or_create(user=request.user, is_active=True) cart_item, created = CartItem.objects.get_or_create( cart=cart, product=saved_item.product, defaults={'quantity': 1} ) if not created: cart_item.quantity += 1 cart_item.save() saved_item.delete() return redirect('cart:cart_detail') # -------------------------- # Extra Utility Views # -------------------------- def quick_view(request, pk): product = get_object_or_404(Product, pk=pk) return render(request, 'products/quick_view_partial.html', {'product': product}) def clear_cart(request): cart = get_cart_for_user(request) cart_items = CartItem.objects.filter(cart=cart) for item in cart_items: product = item.product product.quantity += item.quantity product.save() cart_items.delete() cart.is_active = False cart.save() messages.success(request, "Cart cleared.") return redirect('cart:cart_detail') def test_session(request): request.session['test'] = 'Session OK' return HttpResponse(f"Session: {request.session.get('test')}") this is my views

✅ 1. Update your products/views.py

If you don’t have a view for listing products, add this:

python
# products/views.py

from django.shortcuts import render
from .models import Product
from django.db.models import Q

def product_list(request):
    query = request.GET.get('q')
    products = Product.objects.all()

    if query:
        products = products.filter(
            Q(name__icontains=query) |
            Q(description__icontains=query)
        )

    return render(request, 'products.html', {
        'products': products,
        'cart_count': get_cart_count(request)  # if you want to show cart items count
    })

If you already have product_list, just add the query handling part above.

✅ 2. (Optional) Add Utility Function for cart_count

If you're showing cart count ({{ cart_count }}), add this to the top of products/views.py:

python
from cart.views import get_cart_for_user
from cart.models import CartItem
from django.db.models import Sum

def get_cart_count(request):
    cart = get_cart_for_user(request)
    return CartItem.objects.filter(cart=cart).aggregate(total=Sum('quantity'))['total'] or 0

✅ 3. Ensure urls.py in products/urls.py is set

Make sure your URL route is named products (used in your template's <a href="{% url 'products' %}">):

python
# products/urls.py

from django.urls import path
from . import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('', views.product_list, name='products'),
]

And in your project-level urls.py, include it:

python
# project/urls.py
urlpatterns = [
    ...
    path('products/', include('products.urls')),
]

✨ Bonus CSS Animation (Optional):

If you're using TailwindCSS ≥3.0, most animations like animate-spin, animate-bounce, and animate-pulse are built-in.

If you want something custom like fade-in-up, you can define it manually:

html
<style>
@keyframes fade-in-up {
  0% {
    opacity: 0;
    transform: translateY(20px);
  }
  100% {
    opacity: 1;
    transform: translateY(0);
  }
}
.animate-fade-in-up {
  animation: fade-in-up 0.6s ease-out both;
}
</style>

ChatGPT said:

The error you're encountering:

pgsql
django.template.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: Invalid block tag on line 106: 'elif'. Did you forget to register or load this tag?

is caused because Django's template language doesn't support elif directly outside of {% if %}...{% else %} blocks. Instead, you need to use {% if %}, {% elif %}, and {% else %} properly nested.

But Django templates actually don't support elif at all — instead, you must use {% if %}, {% elif %} as {% if %} followed by {% elif %} as {% else %} + {% if %}.

✅ Fix: Replace this incorrect block

This is your incorrect code:

django
{% if order.order_status == 'pending' %}
  ...
{% elif order.order_status == 'processing' %}
  ...
{% elif order.order_status == 'shipped' %}
  ...
{% elif order.order_status == 'delivered' %}
  ...
{% else %}
  ...
{% endif %}

✅ Corrected Django Template Format:

django
{% if order.order_status == 'pending' %}
  ...pending block...
{% else %}
  {% if order.order_status == 'processing' %}
    ...processing block...
  {% else %}
    {% if order.order_status == 'shipped' %}
      ...shipped block...
    {% else %}
      {% if order.order_status == 'delivered' %}
        ...delivered block...
      {% else %}
        ...fallback...
      {% endif %}
    {% endif %}
  {% endif %}
{% endif %}

Yes — it's verbose, but it's the correct and only safe way in Django templates.

🛠 Recommendation

Wherever you’re using {% elif %} in your template (e.g., inside order_success.html), change it to the nested {% else %} {% if %} format to resolve the error.

ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing:

pgsql
UnboundLocalError: cannot access local variable 'full_name' where it is not associated with a value

means that the variable full_name is being used before it's been defined — probably because your checkout_view is expecting POST data but is being accessed via a GET request.

✅ How to Fix It

Wrap the part of your code that accesses POST variables like full_name in a conditional block so it only runs on POST requests.

✅ Example Fix in checkout_view:

python
from django.shortcuts import render, redirect
from django.utils import timezone
from datetime import timedelta

def checkout_view(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        full_name = request.POST.get('full_name')
        email = request.POST.get('email')
        delivery_method = request.POST.get('delivery_method', 'standard')

        # Estimate delivery
        if delivery_method == 'free':
            estimated_delivery = timezone.now().date()
        elif delivery_method == 'standard':
            estimated_delivery = timezone.now().date() + timedelta(days=3)
        else:
            estimated_delivery = timezone.now().date() + timedelta(days=2)

        # Save the order...
        # Order.objects.create(full_name=full_name, ..., estimated_delivery=estimated_delivery)

        return redirect('checkout:order_success')

    else:
        # On GET request, show the checkout page
        return render(request, 'checkout/checkout.html')

✅ Summary of Fixes:

  • Only access full_name and other POST data inside the if request.method == 'POST' block.

  • For GET requests, just render the template.

ChatGPT said:

Great question! To support order cancellation in your Django e-commerce app, you'll need to add functionality in both:

🔧 1. Model-Level Support

In your Order model (if not already present), ensure you have an order_status field:

python
# Example in models.py
STATUS_CHOICES = [
    ('pending', 'Pending'),
    ('processing', 'Processing'),
    ('shipped', 'Shipped'),
    ('delivered', 'Delivered'),
    ('cancelled', 'Cancelled'),  # ✅ Add this
]

order_status = models.CharField(max_length=20, choices=STATUS_CHOICES, default='pending')

🌐 2. Create a Cancel View

In checkout/views.py, add this:

python
from django.contrib.auth.decorators import login_required

@login_required
def cancel_order(request, order_id):
    order = get_object_or_404(Order, id=order_id, user=request.user)

    if order.order_status in ['pending', 'processing']:  # Only allow early cancellation
        order.order_status = 'cancelled'
        order.save()

        # Optional: Refund stock
        for item in order.items.all():
            item.product.quantity += item.quantity
            item.product.save()

        # Optional: Notify user
        send_mail(
            subject=f"Order #{order.id} Cancelled",
            message=f"Dear {order.full_name},\n\nYour order has been cancelled successfully.",
            from_email=settings.DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL,
            recipient_list=[order.email],
        )

        messages.success(request, "Order has been cancelled.")
    else:
        messages.error(request, "You cannot cancel this order at this stage.")

    return redirect('checkout:track_order', order_id=order.id)

🔗 3. Add URL

In checkout/urls.py:

python
path('cancel-order/<int:order_id>/', views.cancel_order, name='cancel_order'),

🧩 4. Add Cancel Button (Conditionally)

In your order_success.html or track_order.html, show the button only for pending or processing statuses:

html
{% if order.order_status in 'pending processing' %}
  <a href="{% url 'checkout:cancel_order' order.id %}"
     class="px-4 py-2 bg-red-600 text-white rounded-full hover:bg-red-700">
     Cancel Order
  </a>
{% endif %}

✅ Optional Enhancements:

  • Send cancellation email to admin too.

  • Add a "reason for cancellation" field via a form.

  • Disable cancellation if payment is confirmed or order is shipped.

Perfect! Here's how you can implement a confirmation popup/modal before cancelling an order — keeping it user-friendly and styled with TailwindCSS.

✅ Step-by-Step Setup

1. ✅ Add the "Cancel Order" Button

In your order_success.html or track_order.html, replace your previous button with this one:

html
{% if order.order_status in 'pending processing' %}
  <button onclick="openCancelModal()" 
          class="px-4 py-2 bg-red-600 text-white rounded-full hover:bg-red-700 transition duration-200">
    Cancel Order
  </button>
{% endif %}

2. ✅ Add the Modal HTML (hidden by default)

Place this right before the closing </body> tag:

html
<!-- Cancel Order Modal -->
<div id="cancelModal" class="fixed inset-0 bg-black bg-opacity-50 flex items-center justify-center z-50 hidden">
  <div class="bg-white p-6 rounded-2xl shadow-xl w-full max-w-sm text-center">
    <h2 class="text-xl font-bold text-red-600 mb-4">Cancel Order?</h2>
    <p class="text-gray-700 mb-6">Are you sure you want to cancel this order? This action cannot be undone.</p>
    
    <div class="flex justify-center gap-4">
      <button onclick="closeCancelModal()" 
              class="px-4 py-2 rounded-full border border-gray-300 text-gray-700 hover:bg-gray-100">
        No, Keep Order
      </button>
      <a href="{% url 'checkout:cancel_order' order.id %}" 
         class="px-4 py-2 bg-red-600 text-white rounded-full hover:bg-red-700">
        Yes, Cancel
      </a>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

3. ✅ Add JavaScript to Control the Modal

Also near the bottom of your template (before </body>), add:

html
<script>
  function openCancelModal() {
    document.getElementById('cancelModal').classList.remove('hidden');
  }

  function closeCancelModal() {
    document.getElementById('cancelModal').classList.add('hidden');
  }
</script>

🎉 Final Result

When users click the "Cancel Order" button:

  • A stylish modal will pop up.

  • It confirms if the user really wants to cancel.

  • If confirmed, the user is redirected to /cancel-order/<id>/ and the order is marked cancelled.

Absolutely! Let's walk through how to introduce "Order Cancelled" status on your Order Success page with a styled message, animation, and proper conditional display.

✅ Step 1: Add "cancelled" as a valid order_status

First, ensure in your Order model that you have "cancelled" as an option:

python
ORDER_STATUS_CHOICES = [
    ('pending', 'Pending'),
    ('processing', 'Processing'),
    ('shipped', 'Shipped'),
    ('delivered', 'Delivered'),
    ('cancelled', 'Cancelled'),  # <-- Add this
]

Then run makemigrations and migrate if needed.

✅ Step 2: Add a “Cancel Order” button (optional)

If the order is still pending, you can allow the user to cancel it:

html
{% if order.order_status == 'pending' %}
  <form method="POST" action="{% url 'checkout:cancel_order' order.id %}" class="flex-1">
    {% csrf_token %}
    <button type="submit"
            class="w-full px-6 py-3 bg-red-500 text-white rounded-full font-semibold hover:bg-red-600 transition duration-200 shadow">
      Cancel Order
    </button>
  </form>
{% endif %}

✅ Step 3: Handle Cancel Logic in Views

In your views.py, add this view:

python
from django.views.decorators.http import require_POST

@require_POST
def cancel_order_view(request, order_id):
    order = get_object_or_404(Order, id=order_id)
    if order.order_status == 'pending':  # Only allow cancel if pending
        order.order_status = 'cancelled'
        order.save()
        messages.success(request, 'Your order has been cancelled.')
    else:
        messages.error(request, 'Order cannot be cancelled at this stage.')
    return redirect('checkout:order_success', order_id=order.id)

And add to urls.py:

python
path('order-cancel/<int:order_id>/', views.cancel_order_view, name='cancel_order'),

✅ Step 4: Show "Order Cancelled" UI on the success page

Add this below your existing animation block:

html
{% elif order.order_status == 'cancelled' %}
  <div class="flex items-center gap-2 text-red-600 text-sm animate-fade-in-up">
    <svg class="w-6 h-6 text-red-600 animate-pop" fill="currentColor" viewBox="0 0 24 24">
      <path fill-rule="evenodd"
            d="M12 2a10 10 0 100 20 10 10 0 000-20zm-3 7a1 1 0 011.707-.707L12 10.586l1.293-1.293A1 1 0 0115 9.414L13.414 11l1.293 1.293A1 1 0 0113.586 14L12 12.414 10.707 13.707A1 1 0 019.293 12.293L10.586 11 9.293 9.707A1 1 0 019 9z"
            clip-rule="evenodd"/>
    </svg>
    <span class="font-medium">Order Cancelled – We're sorry!</span>
  </div>

🧪 Optional: You can also style the order status badge

Update your status badge styling block:

html
{% elif order.order_status == 'cancelled' %}
  bg-red-100 text-red-800 border border-red-300
